Software Engineering Project - Course Guide

Announcements

Revisions

Introduction

The Software Engineering Project (SE Project) is the capstone of semester 5. After completing the module exams, you and your teammates will work intensively on a real-world software project, applying your accumulated knowledge to a larger, more complex challenge.

Over several weeks, you will research, design, and deliver professional-quality software while gaining experience with unfamiliar technologies, methods, and workflows.

In parallel, your Bachelor’s thesis (BAP) develops as a structured account of your work. It documents the reasoning behind your choices, the evidence that supports them, and the lessons learned throughout the process.

The SE Project and the BAP are therefore tightly connected: your project provides the practice and the technical skills, while your thesis captures and defends your approach.

The SE Project bridges the gap between classroom assignments and professional practice, preparing you to work—and contribute—as a software engineer.

On this page

  • Learning outcomes
  • Expectations
  • How the course runs (at a glance)
  • Timeline snapshot (S5)
  • Coaching model
  • Deliverables and milestones
  • Assessment
  • Team formation and project selection
  • Start exploring projects
  • Final note

Learning outcomes

By the end of this course, you will be able to:

  • Apply existing knowledge to new and unfamiliar problems.
  • Investigate and evaluate technologies, and translate research into well-founded decisions.
  • Deliver professional-quality software: tested, documented, and maintainable.
  • Work effectively in a small team using professional workflows (e.g., GitHub, CI/CD, issue tracking).
  • Communicate results clearly through code, documentation, presentations, and your thesis.
  • Reflect on your own engineering practice and argue for your decisions with evidence.

Expectations

The SE Project requires the same mindset as a professional software development team:

  • Workload: expect a full-time commitment during project weeks, balancing coding, research, documentation, and collaboration.
  • Autonomy: teams are responsible for their own planning, problem solving, and progress. Coaches support and advise, but do not take over daily steering.
  • Professional quality: deliverables should meet standards of reliability, reproducibility, and clarity.

See details: House Rules

How the course runs (at a glance)

  • Teams of 3 choose from a catalog of lecturer-proposed topics and submit 5 preferences; duplicates across teams are allowed.
  • Week 1 focuses on research before implementation begins.
  • The BAP runs alongside the project; key milestones are aligned.
  • Coaching is provided weekly (technical) and at a steady cadence (project coaching: weekly first two weeks, then bi-weekly).
  • The course concludes with an oral exam and BAP evaluation.

See details: Planning and Project selection and teams.

Timeline snapshot (S5)

  • 15/09–25/10: Regular classes (modules)
  • 27/10–01/11: Autumn break
  • 03/11–08/11: Class/buffer week
  • 10/11–22/11: Module exam period
  • 24/11–20/12: SE Project + BAP (project weeks)
  • 22/12–03/01: Winter/work break
  • 05/01–17/01: SE Project + BAP (continue)
  • 19/01–24/01: Project oral exams + BAP evaluation

See details: Planning

Coaching model

Project coaching:

progress and approach. Weekly during the first two weeks, then bi-weekly. Scheduled early in the week.

Technical coaching:

one half-day per week, on demand via a booking system.

More in: Coaching.

Deliverables and milestones

See details: Planning

Assessment

  • Group score: delivery quality, teamwork, and peer evaluation.
  • Individual score: oral technical defense during the exam window.

Rubric and weights: Grading.

Team formation and project selection

  • Teams consist of 3 students.
  • Submit 5 project preferences via the provided form; allocations are confirmed by coach.

Guidelines: Project selection and teams.

Start exploring projects

Browse the catalog: Projects.

Final note

The SE Project is more than a course: it is your first step into professional software engineering practice.

By the end, you will have produced not only software and a thesis, but also a portfolio example that demonstrates your ability to learn fast, collaborate effectively, and defend your decisions—skills that will serve you well in your career as a software engineer.

Project selection and teams

This page explains how to choose a project, how teams are formed, and what is expected once allocations are made.

On this page

  • Key information
  • How project selection works
  • Submit your team and choices

Key information

  • Form a team of 3 (choose a clear team name).
  • Pick 5 project preferences from the catalog (duplicates across teams are allowed).
  • Submit preferences with a short motivation via the selection form (deadline: 24 Oct, 23:59).
  • Allocations announced 27 Oct on Announcements.
  • ⚠️ No reallocation after publication — choose wisely.

See also: Planning, Coaching, Deliverables & deadlines, and the project catalog: Projects.

How project selection works

Step 1 – Form a team

  • Teams consist of 3 students; exceptions only with explicit coach approval.
  • Teams are self-formed; coach will only assign students who cannot find a team (notify coach before the submission deadline).
  • Choose a team name and use it consistently in all communication.
  • Aim for complementary skills and interests.

Step 2 – Explore the catalog

  • Read the short description and learning outcomes for each project.
  • Discuss with your team which topics fit your interests and the skills you want to grow.

Step 3 – Submit your preferences

  • One submission per team.

  • Provide:

    • Team name + members (full name + student email)
    • Your top 5 ranked project choices (1 = highest priority)
    • A short motivation (2–4 sentences or bullet points) for each choice: what you want to learn and why this project fits your goals

  • Use the forms at the bottom of this page: Team submission form and Project preferences form.

Step 4 – Allocation

  • Coach assigns projects based on: team preferences, balance across topics, motivation, and capacity.
  • Duplicates are possible: more than one team may work on the same project.
  • If multiple teams want the same project, ties are resolved fairly.

Step 5 – Confirmation

  • Allocations are published on 27 Oct on Announcements.
  • ⚠️ Allocations are final — no changes after publication.

Submit your team and choices

  • Team submission: Team submission form — coming soon Prepare the following before the form opens:

    • Team name (use consistently in all communication)
    • 3 members: full name + student email

  • Project preferences: Project preferences form — coming soon Prepare the following:

    • Your team name (exactly as submitted above)

    • Your top 5 project choices (ranked)

    • A short motivation (2–4 sentences or bullet points) for each choice:

      • What your team wants to learn
      • Why the topic fits your goals

⚠️ Reminder: No reallocation after publication — choose carefully.

Note: Links will also appear on Announcements when the forms go live.

Coaching

Please read this page before contacting any coach. Always come prepared: agenda, questions, and artifacts ready.

On this page

  • Coaches and roles
  • Contact policy and availability

Coaches and roles

  • Dimitri Casier — organiser and project coach (email)
  • Coach 1 — project coach
  • Coach 2 — project coach
  • Coach 3 — project coach
  • Coach 4 — project coach
  • Coach 5 — project coach

Contact policy and availability

  • Dimitri Casier

    • First contact for team dynamics, conflicts, workload concerns, and unresolved project questions.
    • Use scheduled coaching sessions first; if still blocked, contact via email or Teams.

  • Other coaches

    • Provide on‑demand, supportive technical advice during defined coaching moments only.
    • Book via the tool or use published slots on the Announcements page.

Before contacting a coach (quick checklist)

  1. Read this page and the course docs (Planning, Teams & Projects, House Rules, Grading).
  2. Read your project description/spec.
  3. Use the scheduled coaching moments first (project and technical).
  4. If still blocked, contact Dimitri Casier. For group‑working issues, contact only Dimitri Casier.

Coaching cadence

See dates and the week‑by‑week schedule in Planning.

Project coaching

Details
FrequencyWeekly for the first two weeks, then bi‑weekly; scheduled early in the week.
PurposeProgress review, scope and planning alignment, risk management, team process.
Who attendsThe full team.
Format20min
PrepareShort agenda in a repo issue, current status, brief demo of latest work, top blockers, goals for next sprint.
OutcomesAgreed decisions, updated plan/issues, assigned action items recorded in the repo.

Technical coaching

Details
FrequencyOne half‑day per week; book a slot via the tool (link on the Announcements page).
PurposeDeep technical unblocking and design guidance.
Who attendsRelevant team members (include the person closest to the problem).
PrepareMinimal reproducible example, logs/traces, constraints, alternatives already considered, specific questions.
OutcomesRecommended options with trade‑offs, concrete next steps, references/examples where useful.
EtiquetteTargeted questions only; not a replacement for self‑study or routine code review.

House rules

House rules (planning‑related)

  • Full‑time commitment during project weeks; attend coaching prepared.
  • Keep main releasable; protect with PR reviews and CI.
  • Communicate blockers early via issues; align team availability each week.

Projects

Projects catalog

This page explains what a project is in this course, how each brief is structured, what research is expected, and lists the available topics.

On this page

  • What is a project?
  • Structure of each project brief
  • Research expectations
  • How to use this catalog
  • Available projects

What is a project?

A lecturer‑proposed, real‑world topic executed by a team of three. You will investigate unfamiliar technologies, make and defend engineering decisions, and deliver a working, documented, and tested solution. Your Bachelor’s thesis (BAP) runs in parallel to capture rationale, evidence, and reflection.

See also: Project selection and teams, Planning, Coaching.

Code availability and usability requirements

  • Host all project code in a public GitHub repository owned by your team.
  • Deliver a ready‑to‑use artifact (app, library, CLI, or framework).
  • Make installation and deployment a breeze:
    • One‑command setup (e.g., make up, docker compose up, or a single install script).
    • Libraries: publish install instructions via the package manager (e.g., npm/JSR) and include runnable examples.
    • Provide env.example and sensible default configs.
  • Document clearly:
    • README with Quick start, Features, Usage, Configuration, and Troubleshooting.
    • Installation/deployment guide (local and, if relevant, containerized/cloud).
    • Architecture overview and contribution/development notes.
  • Use GitHub as your workflow hub:
    • Commit and push regularly (daily during project weeks).
    • Develop on feature branches;
    • Keep main protected and green (CI on push/PR).
    • Track work with Issues and a project board; link PRs to issues.

These requirements apply to all topics in this catalog.

Documentation Cheatsheet

Minimum files

  • README.md — Quick start, usage, config, tests, architecture link
  • LICENSE — MIT or Apache-2.0
  • .env.example — sample environment variables
  • CHANGELOG.md — notable changes
  • .github/workflows/ci.yml — CI on push/PR
  • src/, tests/ — code and tests

Pull Request checklist@

  • One-command run works on a clean machine
  • README updated (Quick start, Usage, Config, Tests)
  • CI green (lint/test/build)
  • .env.example present, no secrets in repo
  • CHANGELOG.md updated

README sections (order)

  1. Quick start (3 steps, copy-paste commands)
  2. Features (3–6 bullets)
  3. Usage (examples or CLI/API calls)
  4. Configuration (.env keys explained)
  5. Tests (npm test / deno test / go test)
  6. Troubleshooting (2–4 common issues)

CI essentials

  • Trigger on push + PR
  • Steps: checkout → setup runtime → install → lint → test → build
  • Keep lint/build optional via --if-present

Structure of each project brief

Each project page follows a consistent structure so you can compare topics easily:

  • Title
  • Project description
    • Goal
    • Context
    • Desired outcome
      • Functional requirements
      • Non‑functional requirements
  • Project requirements
  • Useful information

This mirrors the course template and the expectations used for grading and deliverables.

Research guideline (for all projects)

Use this step-by-step guideline during your discovery phase. It is based on the selected steps (research question, core concepts, comparison, technology choices, publication/OSS, vision/philosophy, alternatives).

1) Research question or objective

Define the central question and what success looks like.

  • What problem are you solving and for whom?
  • Success criteria: measurable outcomes (e.g., latency < Xs, DX goals, feature scope).
  • Scope: in/out; assumptions and constraints.

Deliverables

  • 1–2 sentence research question.
  • Success criteria and initial scope (bullets).

2) Core concepts to master

List and explain the foundational ideas for your topic.

  • Examples: CQRS; Event Sourcing vs direct updates; Eventual vs Strong consistency; Polyglot persistence; ORM patterns; agent workflows; rendering/reactivity.
  • Add short definitions and links to 1–2 authoritative sources per concept.
  • Optional: tiny spikes/prototypes to verify understanding.

Deliverables

  • Concept notes (bullets + sources).
  • Optional spike results (code snippets/screens).

3) Comparative analysis (existing solutions)

Survey relevant libraries, frameworks, or architectures.

  • Compare on: flexibility, performance, extensibility, reliability, community, docs, licensing.
  • Capture trade‑offs and “lessons learned” that shape your design.
  • Include minimal experiments if feasible (benchmarks, API ergonomics trials).

Deliverables

  • Comparison table + short summary (what you’ll adopt/avoid).
  • Links to references and any micro-benchmarks.

4) Technology platforms & frameworks

Propose candidate stacks and justify the final choice.

  • Candidates across: storage (NoSQL/RDBMS), messaging/event brokers, language/runtime, UI/CLI.
  • Criteria: fit for purpose, complexity, team skills, ecosystem maturity, constraints (licensing, platform limits).
  • Validate with small PoCs (e.g., connectivity, schema evolution, throughput).

Deliverables

  • Evaluation matrix for the chosen stack.
  • PoC notes (scripts, compose file, or minimal code).

5) Publication & open-source strategy

Plan how you will publish, version, and support your work.

  • Public GitHub repository, license (MIT/Apache‑2.0), issue templates.
  • CI/CD: build, lint, test on PR; main stays green; tagged releases; CHANGELOG.
  • Distribution: npm/JSR for libraries, container images or scripts for apps/CLIs.
  • Documentation standard: README (Quick start, Usage, Config, Troubleshooting)

Deliverables

  • Repo scaffold (LICENSE, README, CI workflow, .env.example).
  • Release/publishing checklist (how to cut a release).

6) Vision and design philosophy

Clarify the intent, principles, and non‑goals.

  • Problems solved and unique value; target users and usage scenarios.
  • Guiding principles (simplicity, extensibility, determinism, operability, DX).
  • Non‑functional priorities (reliability, performance, maintainability).

Deliverables

  • Vision note (1 page max) with principles and non‑goals.
  • High‑level architecture sketch (components and flows).

7) Alternatives considered

Record key decisions and rejected options.

  • For each major decision: context, options, criteria, decision, consequences, evidence.
  • link to experiments and comparisons.

Project: Design and Build a TypeScript ORM Library (Deno/JSR) with Multi-Database Support

Project Description

In this project, you will work as a team to design and implement an Object-Relational Mapping (ORM) library in TypeScript, optimized for the Deno runtime and published via JSR. The ORM should abstract common database operations across multiple relational databases and offer developers a clean, safe, and extensible API. Optionally, it may be extended to support NoSQL datastores or Node.js compatibility.

This project emphasizes both technical depth (patterns, architecture, performance, security) and professional practices (teamwork, iterative workflow, documentation, and open-source release).

Goal

Deliver a robust, modular, and reusable ORM library that enables developers to quickly and safely integrate databases into their applications. The focus should be on:

  • Ease of use (approachable interface, quick setup)
  • Reliability (well-tested, secure)
  • Extensibility (easy to add new drivers, features)
  • Maintainability (clean architecture, strong documentation)

Context

The rise of modern JavaScript runtimes like Deno, combined with the diversity of available databases, has created demand for lightweight, platform-agnostic ORMs. Many existing solutions target Node.js or a single database. This project explores a Deno-first, standards-based ORM that can evolve to support multiple backends and potentially interoperate with Node.js.

Desired Outcome

A stable and well-documented ORM library that:

  • Works out-of-the-box (one-command setup)
  • Supports typical CRUD operations, relations, transactions, and migrations
  • Provides a query builder DSL with method chaining
  • Is published on JSR and open-sourced on GitHub
  • Includes tests, runnable examples, CI/CD pipeline, and architecture documentation

Example DSL (you will define the exact API):

const users = await orm.query('User')
  .where('age', '>', 18)
  .orderBy('createdAt', 'desc')
  .limit(10)
  .execute();

Functional Requirements

Must-Haves

  • Implemented in TypeScript, compatible with Deno, and publishable via JSR

  • Support at least 3 relational databases (e.g., PostgreSQL, MySQL/MariaDB, SQLite) through adapters/drivers

  • Provide:

    • CRUD operations
    • Relations (1-N, N-N, etc.)
    • Transactions and schema migrations
    • Query builder DSL with chaining

  • Local dev setup with Docker Compose for databases

Could-Haves

  • Support for at least one NoSQL database via the same adapter interface
  • CLI tool for schema/migration management
  • Node.js/NPM compatibility layer
  • Plug-in system for custom drivers or behaviors
  • Optimizations: eager vs lazy loading, batching, connection pooling

Non-Functional Requirements

  • Testability: high coverage on core modules (unit + integration)

  • Modularity: clear separation of core, adapters, and drivers (Ports & Adapters recommended)

  • Security: parameterized queries, safe credential handling, protection against SQL injection, mass assignment, etc.

  • Performance: basic benchmarks (CRUD throughput, relation fetches)

  • Documentation:

    • README (Quick start, Features, Troubleshooting)
    • API docs (TSDoc/Typedoc)
    • Architecture notes and decision records
    • Example projects

  • Release & OSS: GitHub repo, MIT/Apache-2.0 license, CI/CD with lint/test/build, changelog, SemVer, tagged releases

Research & Decision Making

You are expected to:

  • Compare ORM patterns (Active Record vs Data Mapper, etc.)
  • Explore migration strategies and query APIs
  • Benchmark adapter performance
  • Record major choices as Architecture Decision Records (ADRs)
  • Study existing ORMs for inspiration (API ergonomics, migrations, driver design)

Project Requirements

  • Team size: 3 students

  • Workflow: Agile/Scrum/Kanban (iterative with code reviews)

  • Repository: GitHub repo with issues/boards

  • Setup: One-command startup (e.g., deno task dev or docker compose up)

  • Environment: .env.example with defaults (no secrets in repo)

  • CI/CD: Linting, testing, building on push

  • Deliverables:

    • Source code + documentation in GitHub
    • Example apps and runnable demos
    • Research report & ADRs
    • Final presentation and reflection

  • Research:

    • Follow the Research guideline (research question, core concepts, comparative analysis, technology evaluation).
    • Run small experiments/benchmarks where relevant and cite evidence.

Assessment Criteria

  1. Research & Analysis – quality of investigation and justification of choices
  2. Functional Working – completeness, stability, usability
  3. Technical Quality – architecture, testability, performance, security
  4. Documentation – clarity, completeness, accessibility
  5. Teamwork & Process – iteration, collaboration, use of tools
  6. Presentation & Reflection – ability to explain and defend your solution

Definition of Done

The project is done when:

  • Research completed and documented:
    • Research question, core concepts, and comparative analysis are written up
    • Experiments/benchmarks included where relevant
  • The ORM meets all must-have requirements
  • At least 3 RDBMS adapters are working
  • All tests pass in CI/CD with high coverage
  • Documentation is complete
  • The library is published via JSR and open-sourced
  • At least one example project demonstrates usage
  • Team delivers final presentation and reflection

Project: Build a CQRS Synchronization between MongoDB (Write) and MySQL (Read)

Project Description

In this project, your team will design and build a system that keeps two different databases in sync:

  • MongoDB – the write database (for storing incoming data).
  • MySQL – the read database (for fast queries, reporting, or analytics).

You will use the CQRS (Command Query Responsibility Segregation) pattern to separate writes (commands to MongoDB) from reads (queries on MySQL).

The main challenge: when data changes in MongoDB, those changes must quickly and reliably appear in MySQL. There are multiple ways to achieve this (see below), but in practice many systems use an event broker (e.g., RabbitMQ, Kafka, or NATS). For this project, you are free to choose your approach, but using a broker is recommended as it reflects industry best practice.

Goal

Deliver a working synchronization system that:

  • Detects changes in MongoDB.
  • Propagates these changes to MySQL using your chosen method (direct projector, change streams, outbox, or broker).
  • Keeps MySQL in sync in near real-time with minimal latency.
  • Includes a demo application with a domain and entities (DDD-inspired), so the CQRS pattern is demonstrated with realistic business logic.
  • Is easy to run locally (one-command startup with Docker).
  • Comes with clear documentation and examples so others can use it.

Context

In real-world systems, developers often separate:

  • Write models – optimized for saving domain data (e.g., MongoDB with aggregates/entities).
  • Read models – optimized for querying and reporting (e.g., MySQL projections).

This project gives you hands-on experience with data synchronization, event-driven systems, CQRS, and domain-driven design (DDD).

You can implement synchronization in several ways:

  1. Direct projector
  2. MongoDB Change Streams
  3. Transactional Outbox
  4. Event Broker (recommended)

Desired Outcome

A system that:

  • Keeps MySQL in sync with MongoDB writes.
  • Uses a domain model with entities and aggregates to make the CQRS pattern concrete.
  • Handles restarts and recoveries without losing data.
  • Runs locally with a single command (docker compose up).
  • Includes a demo app that shows synchronization in action (with realistic domain entities).
  • Is well documented, tested, and open-sourced on GitHub.

Functional Requirements

Must-Haves

  • Implement a domain model with entities (DDD-inspired) for the write side.
  • Detect changes in MongoDB.
  • Update MySQL projections using one of the chosen approaches.
  • Guarantee idempotent updates (no duplicates).
  • Provide recovery/replay so the system can catch up after restarts.
  • Deliver a demo app that shows synchronization flow.
  • Supply a Docker Compose setup (MongoDB, MySQL, and optional broker).
  • Document your setup, design choices, and usage.

Could haves

  • Add monitoring (metrics/logs, dashboard, or CLI).
  • Handle schema changes over time (e.g., adding/renaming fields).
  • Retry logic and dead-letter queue for failed events.
  • Introduce Event Sourcing: store domain events as the source of truth and rebuild projections from the event log.
  • Blue/green rebuild of the read database without downtime.

Non-Functional Requirements

  • Reliability: no data loss on restart; consistent updates.
  • Performance: synchronization within a few seconds.
  • Testability: ≥ 80% test coverage.
  • Observability: logs and metrics that show system state.
  • Reproducibility: one-command setup (Docker Compose).
  • Documentation: README and demo examples.

Research & Decision Making

You must research and justify your design decisions, including:

  • Which synchronization approach you chose (direct, change streams, outbox, or broker).
  • Why you did (or didn’t) use a broker.
  • How you guarantee ordering, idempotency, and recovery.
  • How you designed your domain model (entities/aggregates).
  • Whether you considered or experimented with event sourcing.
  • Record decisions as Architecture Decision Records (ADRs).

Project Requirements

  • Team size: 3 students.

  • Workflow: Agile/Scrum/Kanban.

  • Repository: GitHub with issues/boards and clear commits.

  • Setup: One-command run (docker compose up).

  • Environment: .env.example with safe defaults (no secrets).

  • CI/CD: Linting, testing, and building on PRs.

  • Deliverables:

    • Source code + documentation in GitHub.
    • Demo application with a domain model and entities.
    • Research report + ADRs.
    • Final presentation + reflection.

Assessment Criteria

  1. Research & Analysis – quality of investigation and justification of chosen approach.
  2. Functional Working – does the sync pipeline reliably keep MySQL in sync?
  3. Domain Model – does the demo app use a clear domain with entities/aggregates?
  4. Technical Quality – architecture, tests, recovery, observability.
  5. Documentation – clarity and accessibility of docs.
  6. Teamwork & Process – iterative work, collaboration, Git usage.
  7. Presentation & Reflection – ability to explain and defend your solution.

Definition of Done

The project is complete when:

  • Research completed and documented:
    • Research question, core concepts, and comparative analysis are written up
    • Experiments/benchmarks included where relevant
  • A working synchronization system exists (MongoDB → MySQL).
  • The chosen approach is documented and justified.
  • Must-have requirements are met, including a DDD-inspired domain model in the demo.
  • Tests pass with good coverage.
  • Documentation is complete
  • The system runs locally with one command.
  • A demo shows synchronization in action.
  • Final presentation and reflection delivered.

Project: Design and Build a Lightweight Frontend Framework (React/Vue-Inspired)

Project Description

In this project, your team will design and implement a minimal but usable frontend framework inspired by modern libraries such as React, Vue, Preact, Solid, or Svelte.

The goal is not to recreate these frameworks in full, but to understand and implement their core ideas:

  • rendering strategy (virtual DOM diffing or fine-grained reactivity/signals)
  • a simple component model
  • basic state management

You will choose the architecture (runtime vs compile-time), API style (JSX, template, or hyperscript), and packaging strategy. Along the way, you’ll compare alternatives, run experiments, and justify your design choices.

This project emphasizes both technical depth (frontend architecture, rendering strategies, developer experience) and professional practices (teamwork, research, documentation, and iterative delivery).

Goal

Deliver a small, coherent framework and a demo application that show you understand:

  • Component-based rendering
  • State updates and re-rendering
  • Performance trade-offs
  • Developer-friendly APIs

Your framework should be accompanied by tests, examples, and clear documentation.

Context

Popular frameworks like React and Vue hide a lot of complexity. By building your own simplified version, you will gain a deeper understanding of:

  • how rendering works
  • how state changes update the UI
  • how components are structured and re-used
  • what trade-offs exist between simplicity, performance, and developer experience

This knowledge will make you a stronger frontend engineer and help you evaluate or adopt frameworks more critically in the future.

Desired Outcome

A working frontend framework prototype and a demo app that:

  • Renders components declaratively and updates the DOM efficiently when state changes.
  • Supports state, props, and events, with examples of conditional rendering and list rendering.
  • Provides a mount API (e.g., render(App, mountNode)).
  • Runs locally with a one-command setup (npm run dev or similar).
  • Is open-sourced on GitHub, documented, and covered by basic tests.

Functional Requirements

Must-Haves

  • Rendering strategy – choose one:

    • Virtual DOM diffing + patching, or
    • Fine-grained reactivity/signals (no full VDOM).

  • Component model:

    • Components accept props and can hold internal state.
    • Components re-render when state updates.
    • Support for event handling.

  • Core features:

    • Conditional rendering.
    • List rendering.
    • Simple mount API (render(App, mountNode)).

  • Demo app showing off the features.

  • Document your chosen design and justify trade-offs.

Examples (adapt to your API):

const Counter = () => {
  const [count, setCount] = useState(0);
  return h('button', { onClick: () => setCount(count() + 1) }, `Count: ${count()}`);
};
render(Counter, document.getElementById('app')!);

or

<template>
  <button @click="increment">
    Count: {{ count }}
  </button>
</template>

<script>
export default {
  name: 'Counter',
  data() {
    return { count: 0 };
  },
  methods: {
    increment() {
      this.count++;
    },
  },
};
</script>

Could-Haves (Optional, Stretch Goals)

  • JSX or a tiny template parser.
  • Hooks/effects (useEffect, useMemo).
  • Lifecycle hooks (onMount, onUnmount).
  • Context API or signals.
  • A simple router.
  • Keyed list diffing optimizations.
  • Dev tooling (debug logs, render timings).
  • Compile-time transforms (like a tiny compiler).
  • SSR/hydration experiment.
  • A custom renderer (e.g., render to <canvas> instead of the DOM).

Non-Functional Requirements

  • TypeScript or Javascript: strict mode

  • Tests: unit + integration, ≥ 70% coverage on core modules.

  • Modularity: separate core, renderer, and optional JSX/parser.

  • Performance: basic benchmarks (initial render vs update re-render).

  • Build/Distribution: ESM build; optionally publish as npm/JSR package.

  • Documentation:

    • README with Quick Start, Usage, and Troubleshooting.
    • Examples showcasing common use cases.

Research & Decision Making

You are expected to:

  • Compare virtual DOM vs signals/reactivity and justify your choice.
  • Investigate diffing strategies and schedulers.
  • Explore different API designs (JSX vs template vs hyperscript).
  • Run small benchmarks and experiments to support your choices.
  • Look at existing frameworks (React, Vue, Solid, Svelte) for inspiration.

Project Requirements

  • Team size: 3 students.

  • Workflow: Agile/Scrum/Kanban with code reviews.

  • Repository: Public GitHub repo with issues/boards.

  • Setup: One-command run (npm run dev or make up).

  • Environment: .env.example if configuration is needed.

  • CI/CD: Lint, test, and build on pull requests.

  • Deliverables:

    • Framework code + documentation.
    • Example/demo app.
    • Research report
    • Final presentation and reflection.

Assessment Criteria

  1. Research & Analysis – how well you investigated and justified your choices.
  2. Functional Working – does the framework render and update correctly?
  3. Technical Quality – clean code, modularity, test coverage, performance.
  4. Documentation – clear README, API docs, and examples.
  5. Teamwork & Process – iterative development, collaboration, Git workflow.
  6. Presentation & Reflection – ability to explain and defend your framework design.

Definition of Done

The project is complete when:

  • Research and comparative analysis are documented.
  • A minimal but working framework is implemented.
  • Must-have features (components, state, rendering, events, conditional + list rendering) are working.
  • A demo app showcases the framework.
  • Tests pass with reasonable coverage.
  • Documentation (README, ADRs, examples) is complete.
  • The framework can run locally with a single command.
  • Final presentation and reflection delivered.

Project: Pacman and AI Search Algorithms (Toolkit + Maze Demo)

Project Description

Build a small, well-structured AI Search Toolkit that implements and compares classic search algorithms. You will create a reusable library of search algorithms and a demo environment (maze and Pacman-style scenario) to test and visualize them. Focus on correctness, clarity, and evidence-based comparison.

Based on materials from CS50’s AI course, analyze different search techniques and implement them in your chosen programming language (within the course’s allowed runtimes). Reference: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WbzNRTTrX0g

You choose the programming language and architecture, then justify your choices with research and small experiments. Keep the project easy to run, well tested, and documented so others can understand and reuse your work.

Note: For inspiration on agent abstractions and code structure, you can study the AIMA Java codebase:

  • https://github.com/aimacode/aima-java/tree/AIMA3e/aima-core/src/main/java/aima/core
    This is the Java implementation of algorithms from Russell and Norvig’s “Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach (3rd Edition)”.

Goal

Deliver a toolkit and demo that let you:

  • Implement and run several search algorithms on the same problem model.
  • Compare their behavior and performance with clear metrics.
  • Explain trade-offs (completeness, optimality, time/space complexity) in practical terms.

Context

Search algorithms are core to AI (pathfinding, puzzle solving, game AI). Implementing them yourself gives deep understanding of how they work and when to use which. The maze/Pacman demo makes results tangible and fun to evaluate.

Desired Outcome

A working toolkit and demo that:

  • Runs multiple algorithms on the same problems (maze/grid and a simple Pacman-like level).
  • Produces comparable outputs (path found, nodes expanded, cost, time).
  • Is easy to run locally in one command and is documented so others can use it.

Functional Requirements

Must-Haves

  • Implement at least 4 algorithms:
    • Depth-First Search (DFS)
    • Breadth-First Search (BFS)
    • Greedy Best-First Search
    • A* Search (with a heuristic you explain)
  • Common problem model:
    • Same state representation and interface for all algorithms (e.g., grid/maze with walls, start, goal).
  • Reproducible outputs:
    • For a given seed/input, runs produce the same path and metrics.
  • Demo application:
    • CLI or simple UI to select algorithm, load a map, run, and show the result (path + stats).
  • Metrics per run:
    • Nodes expanded, path length/cost, runtime (and optionally memory).

Could-Haves (Optional)

  • Additional algorithms: Iterative Deepening, Dijkstra, Bidirectional Search, Minimax/Alpha-Beta (for adversarial play).
  • Visualizer:
    • Animate exploration order, frontier, and final path.
  • Heuristic experiments:
    • Plug-in heuristics (Manhattan, Euclidean); compare their effects.
  • Benchmark tool:
    • Run many maps and output a comparison table/plot.
  • Pacman behaviors:
    • Ghost logic or collectibles to make scenarios richer.

Non-Functional Requirements

  • Testability:
    • ≥ 80% coverage on core search logic; deterministic tests.
  • Modularity:
    • Separate problem model, algorithms, and demo UI/CLI.
  • Observability:
    • Clear logs for steps/visited nodes (toggleable).
  • Reproducibility:
    • One-command setup/run on a clean machine.
  • Documentation:
    • README with Quick Start, Usage, Configuration, Troubleshooting.
    • Short explanation of each algorithm and heuristic used.

Research & Decision Making

You are expected to:

  • Compare algorithms conceptually:
    • Completeness, optimality, time/space complexity; when to use which.
  • Evaluate heuristics:
    • Why a heuristic is admissible/consistent; impact on A* and Greedy.
  • Run small experiments:
    • Measure nodes expanded, runtime, and path quality on a few maps.
  • Record major choices:
    • Problem model, data structures, heuristics, visualization approach.
    • Keep brief ADRs (Architecture Decision Records) for key decisions.
  • Read the AIMA chapters on Agents and on Search, and consider how agent-based abstractions (environment, agent, percepts, actions) can inform your design. The relevant chapters are available via the provided resources; purchasing the book is not required.

Project Requirements

  • Team size:
    • 3 students.
  • Language/runtime:
    • Everything except Java, reason demo code is in Java
  • Repository (public GitHub):
    • Commit regularly; use issues/board; PR reviews.
    • One-command run (e.g., npm run dev / deno task start / make run).
    • Provide .env.example if configuration is needed; no secrets in repo.
  • CI/CD:
    • Lint, test, and build on pull requests; main stays green.
  • Deliverables:
    • Source code + documentation on GitHub.
    • Demo application (CLI or UI).
    • Research notes and ADRs.
    • Final presentation and reflection.

Assessment Criteria

  1. Research & Analysis:
    • Quality of comparisons, heuristic rationale, and evidence from experiments.
  2. Functional Working:
    • Algorithms run correctly on shared problems; demo is usable.
  3. Technical Quality:
    • Code structure, tests, clarity, and performance basics.
  4. Documentation:
    • Clear README, examples, and explanation of results.
  5. Teamwork & Process:
    • Iterative development, Git workflow, reviews.
  6. Presentation & Reflection:
    • Ability to explain and defend choices; lessons learned.

Definition of Done

The project is complete when:

  • Research completed and documented:
    • Algorithm comparisons and heuristic rationale written up.
    • Experiments/benchmarks (nodes expanded, runtime, path cost) included.
    • ADRs for key decisions present and linked.
  • Functionality:
    • At least DFS, BFS, Greedy, and A* implemented against a common interface.
    • Demo runs on a maze and a small Pacman-style map, showing path and metrics.
  • Quality:
    • Tests pass (≥ 80% coverage on core logic) in CI.
    • Code is modular and readable; logs/metrics available.
  • Delivery:
    • Public GitHub repository with complete README and one-command run.
    • Final presentation and

Project: Build an AI‑Driven Terminal Interface with Plugin Architecture

Project Description

In this project, you will work as a team to design and implement a modern terminal interface focused on developer productivity. Unlike a single CLI tool, you will build a full terminal experience that supports both classical shell commands and natural language prompts. The terminal should understand basic shell commands enhanced with an AI assistant (suggestions, explanations, safe/dry‑run previews) and render interactive block‑based input/output. It can orchestrate multiple AI agents with different roles (explain, execute, debug, etc.) and is extensible via a plugin architecture (at least one AI‑powered plugin).

Inspiration: Warp (https://www.warp.dev/)
Warp is a modern, Rust‑based terminal that showcases:

  • A block‑based interaction model (each command and output is a discrete, shareable block).
  • Smart input UX (command palette, rich completions, inline flag docs, templates/workflows).
  • Collaboration features (shareable blocks/sessions, searchable command history).
  • AI assistance (explain commands, generate command lines from intent, suggest safer alternatives).

Use Warp’s ideas to guide UX and interaction patterns. Do not clone it 1:1—select and justify which ideas you adopt based on your goals and scope.

This project emphasizes both technical depth (architecture, plugins, multi‑agent orchestration, safety) and professional practices (teamwork, iterative workflow, documentation, and open‑source release).

Goal

Deliver an agentic CLI environment that enables:

  • Classic shell usage and natural language input side by side.
  • AI‑enhanced shell commands (suggest flags, explain/dry‑run, warn/confirm risky commands).
  • A modular plugin system (AI and non‑AI).
  • A visual, block‑based UI for input/output.
  • Practical features that help developers (initialize projects, analyze code, generate tests, refactor).

Context

Command‑line tools are central to software engineering. In parallel, AI assistants are reshaping developer workflows. This project combines both by creating a smart, visual, and extensible terminal that leverages AI to improve productivity and team collaboration. Your design should emphasize extensibility, operability, and developer experience.

Desired Outcome

A working terminal application that:

  • Provides a clear command structure with subcommands (e.g., init, run, explain).
  • Supports natural language mode that maps prompts to executable actions.
  • Implements a plugin architecture (discover, load, configure; at least one AI plugin).
  • Renders interactive blocks for inputs/outputs (copy, annotate, expand details).
  • Orchestrates multiple AI agents with different roles.
  • Maintains context memory and supports shared workflows.
  • Includes logging, error handling, tests, and documentation.
  • Runs locally with a one‑command setup.

Functional Requirements

Must‑Haves

  • CLI core and subcommands: e.g., init, run, info, explain.
  • Basic shell commands with AI assistance:
    • Parse and execute common shell commands (ls, cd, cp, mv, rm, git, …).
    • Offer AI suggestions, auto‑corrections, and flag hints.
    • Provide explanations and safe/dry‑run previews before risky actions (e.g., rm -rf, destructive Git ops).
    • Require confirmation for dangerous operations.
  • Natural language mode: user types free text; an AI plugin translates intent into actions/commands.
  • Plugin architecture:
    • Discover, load/unload third‑party plugins (AI and non‑AI).
    • Provide clear extension points and a versioned plugin API.
  • Block‑based UI:
    • Render input/output as interactive blocks (copy, annotate, expand/collapse).
    • Show per‑block status, logs, and errors.
  • Multi‑agent support:
    • Run multiple AI agents (planner, executor, explainer) and route tasks between them.

Could‑Haves (Optional)

  • Plugin examples: refactor, docgen, lint, format, testgen.
  • Team workflows: shared context/workflows across sessions.
  • Integrations: Git, issue trackers, CI.
  • Advanced UX: themes/keybindings, command history visualization.
  • Dashboard: panel for active agents and block history.

Non‑Functional Requirements

  • Shell compatibility: works with Bash, Zsh, Fish, or PowerShell.
  • Reliability & UX: robust error handling; clear prompts; readable colors.
  • Testability: ≥ 70% coverage on core modules (CLI, plugins, agent routing).
  • Modularity: separate CLI, core, and plugins; avoid tight coupling.
  • Observability: per‑block logs; optional verbose tracing.
  • Documentation:
    • README with Quick Start, Usage, Configuration, Troubleshooting.
    • API docs for the plugin interface.
    • Example configurations and workflows.
  • Reproducibility: one‑command local setup; deterministic bootstrap.
  • Security/Safety: guardrails for destructive commands; permission prompts; redact secrets in logs.

Research & Decision Making

You are expected to:

  • Define your vision and philosophy for a modern terminal UX.
  • Compare plugin architectures for CLIs and justify choices (loading, sandboxing, versioning).
  • Explore AI interaction patterns for developer tooling (prompting, grounding, safety).
  • Review multi‑agent orchestration strategies and when they help.
  • Consider shell integration and cross‑platform concerns.
  • Evaluate Warp patterns (blocks, palette, AI help, workflows) and document what you adopt and why.
  • Propose an approach for context memory and collaboration.
  • Record major choices as ADRs (Architecture Decision Records) and include short spikes/experiments.

Project Requirements

  • Team size: 3 students.
  • Runtime: your choice; Rust preferred but not required. JS/TS, Go, etc., are acceptable—justify your pick.
  • Repository: public GitHub; use issues/board and PR reviews.
  • Setup: one‑command run (e.g., cargo run, npm run dev, or make run).
  • Environment: include .env.example; no secrets in the repo.
  • CI/CD: lint, test, and build on PRs; main stays green.
  • Deliverables:
    • Source code + documentation on GitHub.
    • Demo usage and example plugins.
    • Research notes and ADRs.
    • Final presentation and reflection.

Assessment Criteria

  1. Research & Analysis – clarity of goals, comparisons, and evidence.
  2. Functional Working – CLI, natural language mode, plugins, and multi‑agent flow work as specified.
  3. Technical Quality – architecture, modularity, tests, and observability.
  4. Documentation & DX – easy to install, clear usage, plugin API docs, examples.
  5. Teamwork & Process – iterative development, Git workflow, code reviews.
  6. Presentation & Reflection – ability to explain and defend choices; lessons learned.

Definition of Done

The project is done when:

  • Research completed and documented:
    • Vision, comparisons, and key trade‑offs are written up.
    • Experiments/spikes inform decisions; ADRs are present and linked.
  • Functionality:
    • CLI supports both classic commands and natural language.
    • At least one AI plugin is implemented and usable.
    • Plugin architecture is demonstrably extensible (load/unload, versioning).
    • Block‑based UI with per‑block logs and errors is implemented.
  • Quality:
    • Tests pass with ≥ 70% coverage on core modules in CI.
    • Codebase is modular, readable, and observable.
  • Delivery:
    • Public GitHub repository with complete README and one‑command run.
    • Demo showcases core features.
    • Final presentation and reflection delivered.

Project Tags

#cli, #developer-tools, #ai, #plugin-architecture, #typescript (or #rust), #shell, #agentic-dev, #developer-experience
